headline.main: New York State's Ambitious Plan to Grade Hospitals Remains Stalled

docs.lead_paragraph: The failings of hospital care have suddenly become a hot issue. In November, a much-cited report said that 44,000 to 98,000 patients nationwide died each year because of hospital errors. President Clinton, major corporations and health insurers have seized on that news to call for a major effort to raise the quality of care. But an important step toward improving hospital performance is to measure it -- a complex, politically charged undertaking -- and in this, New York was far in front just a few years ago. A 1996 state law on hospital financing commissioned ''report cards'' on hospitals, assessments that would tell consumers how safe it was to have, say, an appendectomy, or a Caesarean section, at any hospital in New York. Nowhere else had such a thing been attempted.
